description: Upright-growing tree. Large, light-green, heart-shaped leaves turn bright-yellow in autumn. A profusion of deep cerise-pink, pea-shaped flowers stud the bare branches for an extended period in early-spring. Ideal for small spaces. Cercis chinensis is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Cercis chinensis. Cercis chinensis 'Avondale' was selected in Avondale, Auckland, New Zealand and introduced by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Large, rich-green, heart-shaped leaves that turn yellow in autumn. Masses of white flowers stud the bare branches in early-spring. Compact-grower. Ideal for the smaller garden. Cercis chinensis is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Cercis chinensis. Cercis chinensis 'Spring Snow' was developed in New Zealand and the name was registered in 2015.

A handsome tree with a flat, spreading crown. Has green, heart-shaped leaves. Pink flowers cover the branches in early-spring. Yellow autumn leaves. Great small tree for dry sites. Hardy. Cercis siliquastrum is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Western Asia. Learn more about Cercis siliquastrum.

A beautiful tree noted for its prolific display of pea-shaped, white flowers in spring. Yellow autumn leaves. Cercis siliquastrum is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Western Asia. Learn more about Cercis siliquastrum. Cercis siliquastrum 'Alba' originated as a natural form of Cercis siliquastrum, originally growing in the Mediterranean area.

Dense-growing, pyramidal form with silver-blue leaves which are soft to touch. Outstanding colour and form. Chamaecyparis pisifera is evergreen and native to central and southern Japan, on the islands of Honshū and Kyūshū. Learn more about Chamaecyparis pisifera. Chamaecyparis pisifera 'Boulevard' originated in 1934 as a sport on a specimen of Chamaecyparis pisifera 'Squarrosa' and was introduced to the nursery trade by Mike Kempenaar of Boulevard Nurseries, Middletown, Rhode Island, United States.

A multi-stemmed, bushy grower. Bare branches are studded with sulphur-yellow flowers in mid-winter. These exude the most delicious fragrance of spice and violets. Grows best in cold climates and dry summers. Yellow autumn leaves. Chimonanthus praecox is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Chimonanthus praecox.

Compact, rounded bush with a distinctive fragrance. Attractive, deep-green leaves. Fantastic for hedging or as a gap filler in the garden. Hardy. Produces clusters of pure-white flowers throughout spring. Tolerates drought and prefers well-drained soils. Choisya ternata is evergreen and native to Mexico. Learn more about Choisya ternata.

A great shade tree with a very picturesque form. New leaves are green with a red tinge and mature to green. Smooth bark. Crushed leaves and twigs exude a camphor fragrance. In spring, produces masses of small white flowers, followed by clusters of black, berry-like fruit during autumn which birds love. Tolerates drought once established. Cinnamomum camphora is evergreen and native to China south of the Yangtze River, Taiwan, southern Japan, Korea, India, and Vietnam. Learn more about Cinnamomum camphora.

Compact grower that is virtually thornless. Grows well in a large pot. Great for small gardens. Prolific crops of large-sized fruit start green but are ready when the fruit changes to yellow-green. Fruit is used for cooking and flavouring drinks. Scented white flowers throughout spring and summer. Self-fertile. Prefers warmer climates and is very sensitive to frost. In tropical climates, will produce limes year-round. However, in subtropical climates, will only produce one yearly crop that usually matures by late-summer (time of fruit maturity depends on the local conditions). Citrus x aurantiifolia is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus micrantha (syn. Citrus hystrix var. micrantha) and Citrus medica. Citrus x aurantiifolia is evergreen and native to tropical Southeast Asia. Learn more about Citrus x aurantiifolia.

A heavier-bearing lime, which is cold-hardy. Upright, bushy grower. Prolific crops of large-sized fruit start green but are ready when the fruit changes to green-yellow. Crops through winter and in summer. Has a high juice content. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x latifolia is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x aurantiifolia and Citrus x limon. Learn more about Citrus x latifolia. Citrus x latifolia 'Bearss' is named after John T. Bearss, who developed this seedless cultivar about 1895 at his nursery in Porterville, California, United States.

Cold-hardy lime for home gardens and quick to commence fruiting. Upright, bushy grower. Prolific crops of large-sized fruit start green but are ready when the fruit changes to yellow-green. Crops through winter. Has a high juice content. Excellent for containers. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x latifolia is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x aurantiifolia and Citrus x limon. Learn more about Citrus x latifolia.

An almost thornless cultivar that produces juicy, highly-sour fruit with very few seeds and a smooth, medium-thin rind. Citrus x limon 'Eureka' is a true lemon so will have a more sour taste than hybrid lemons. Once established, will fruit all year round. Produces the biggest crops in spring and summer. Scented white flowers throughout the year. Self-fertile. Citrus x limon 'Eureka' is less cold-tolerant than other lemon cultivars, so is best for warmer and/or coastal areas where frost damage seldom occurs. Citrus x limon is evergreen and native to Asia, primarily Northeast India (Assam), Northern Myanmar, and China. Learn more about Citrus x limon. Citrus x limon 'Eureka' originated in Los Angeles, California, United States in the late 1800s, possibly having its ancestry from Citrus x limon 'Lunario' from Italy. Citrus x limon 'Eureka' was selected in about 1877 from seedlings that were planted in 1858. C. R. Workman provided Thomas A. Garey with budwood from one of these seedlings and he propagated the first Citrus x limon 'Eureka'.

An almost thornless cultivar that produces juicy, highly-sour fruit with very few seeds. Citrus x limon 'Villa Franca' is a true lemon so will have a more sour taste than hybrid lemons. Fruit ripens in winter. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x limon is evergreen and native to Asia, primarily Northeast India (Assam), Northern Myanmar, and China. Learn more about Citrus x limon. Citrus x limon 'Villa Franca' is said to have originated in Sicily and was then introduced into Florida, United States by H. S. Sandford about 1875 and later into California, United States.

Has a compact growth habit. Citrus x limon 'Yen Ben' is a true lemon so will have a more sour taste than hybrid lemons. The large, oval fruits are tangy and considered excellent for culinary use. The fruit have a high juice content, very few seeds, and a thin rind. Fruit ripens in mid to late-winter. One of the hardiest lemons. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x limon is evergreen and native to Asia, primarily Northeast India (Assam), Northern Myanmar, and China. Learn more about Citrus x limon. Citrus x limon 'Yen Ben' was selected as a sport of Citrus x limon 'Lisbon' at Benyenda Citrus in Queensland, Australia in the late 1930s. Citrus x limon 'Yen Ben' has been trialled in New Zealand since 1978.

Similar to a lemon with pale-yellow fruit. Juicy fruit has a mild, fresh, grapefruit-like flavour. Very refreshing to eat off the tree. A heavy cropper in mid-winter to early-spring, with smaller summer crops sometimes occurring. Excellent for containers. Scented white flowers throughout spring. Self-fertile. Citrus limon x reticulata is evergreen and a hybrid of unknown origin, although it is believed to be a hybrid between a lemon (Citrus x limon) and a mandarin (Citrus reticulata). Citrus limon x reticulata was discovered as a chance seedling in New Zealand in the 1980s.

The most popular lemon for home gardens. Cold-hardy and quick to commence fruiting. Has a low-spreading growth habit which will make a large bush. Large fruit have a high juice content with lower acid level than other cultivars. Citrus x meyeri is a hybrid lemon so will have a sweeter taste than true lemons. Excellent for containers. Once established, will fruit all year round. Produces the biggest crops in autumn and winter. Scented white flowers throughout the year. Self-fertile. Citrus x meyeri is evergreen and most likely a hybrid between Citrus medica and the hybrid formed between Citrus maxima and Citrus reticulata. Citrus x meyeri is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Citrus x meyeri. Citrus x meyeri was discovered growing in Beijing, China by agricultural explorer Frank Nicholas Meyer, an employee of the United States Department of Agriculture, although it was established in China many hundreds of years before he introduced it to America.

Thin-skinned grapefruit with few seeds. Golden-yellow skin with orange flesh. A heavy-bearer that produces juicy, sweet, and tangy grapefruit. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Fruits from mid-winter to late-spring. Self-fertile. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x sinensis and Citrus maxima. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and native to Barbados. Learn more about Citrus x paradisi. Citrus x paradisi 'Golden Special' has been the most common grapefruit cultivar in New Zealand since the 1970s.

synonyms: Citrus x aurantium 'Star Ruby', Citrus x paradisi 'Rio Star', Citrus x aurantium 'Rio Star'
description: Produces abundant crops of juicy, red-fleshed fruit with yellow-orange skins. Fruit ripens from late-winter to mid-spring. The intensity of the red flesh lessens in cooler climates. Fruit holds well on the tree. Low-seeded or seedless in some cases and fruit has a very good flavour. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Prefers warmer climates and will not tolerate cold areas with significant frosts. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and a hybrid between Citrus x sinensis and Citrus maxima. Citrus x paradisi is evergreen and native to Barbados. Learn more about Citrus x paradisi. Citrus x paradisi 'Star Ruby' was produced by R. A. Hensz of Texas A&I University, Texas, United States and released in 1970.

Medium-sized fruit with a thin, yellow-orange rind. Deep-orange, juicy flesh with a rich flavour. Fruits from late-spring to late-summer. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Grows upright with almost no thorns. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata. Citrus reticulata 'Encore' is a hybrid between the King mandarin (Citrus nobilis) and Willowleaf mandarin (Citrus x deliciosa) produced by H. B. Frost and introduced in 1965.

A superior, easy to peel, Satsuma selection with an upright, spreading growth habit. Fruit is sweet and juicy and ripens through winter. Average fruit size is 9cm wide by 4cm deep, usually with 10 segments. Excellent for containers. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Cold-tolerant. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata. Citrus reticulata 'Miho' was selected from seedlings planted in Japan in 1984 and first fruited in 1990.

A seedless, large-fruiting Satsuma selection. Fruit with yellow-orange skin has easy to peel skin and easy to separate segments. Fruits in autumn. White flowers in summer. Self-fertile. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata. Citrus reticulata 'Okitsu' originated as a seedling of Citrus reticulata 'Miyagawa' during a controlled pollination by M. Kajiura and T. Iwasaki at the Horticultural Research Station in Okitsu, Japan. Citrus reticulata 'Okitsu' was distributed for trial in 1953, registered in 1963, and introduced into Europe in 1983.

Easy to peel, cold-hardy mandarin with heavy crops of juicy, mild-flavoured, seedless fruit. Slower-growing and well suited to growing in containers. Fruit ripens in early-winter. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus reticulata is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Citrus reticulata.

Has sweet, juicy, and seedless flesh. Fruits from late-winter to late-spring. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Best's Seedless' was selected in New Zealand.

A sweet, juicy, and seedless cultivar of excellent flavour. Remaining juicy for 2 to 3 months if left on the tree. Fruit ripens in late-winter. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel' is presumed to be a bud variation of unknown origin. Several old trees of this cultivar were noted about 1925 in the A. N. Carter orchard at Sierra Madre, California, United States. Citrus x sinensis 'Carter's Navel' was introduced by Armstrong Nurseries in Ontario, California, United States in 1928.

Produces very juicy and sweet fruit. The fruit are practically seedless and easy to peel. Fruit ripens in late-winter. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis.

Sweet, juicy, seedless fruit with a strong red-orange tinge to the rind. Excellent flavour, ripening in late-winter. Grow in full-sun. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' is believed to be a naturally occurring mutation of a Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' tree that was found in the 1960s in the garden of S. Fukumoto in Kokawa (Kokawa-Cho), Naga District, Wakayama Prefecture, Japan. The tree was donated to an American doctor named W. P. Bitters in 1983. Bitters selected this tree from a display of Japanese citrus trees and then brought Citrus x sinensis 'Fukumoto' to the United States Department of Agriculture quarantine facility in Glenn Dale, Maryland, United States. The tree spent a few years in quarantine before being released in September 1986.

Bright-orange fruit with thin skin. Flesh is firm with a rich, sweet flavour and few seeds. Fruits from mid-spring to early-autumn. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Valencia' was named after the famed sweet oranges produced in València, Spain and was first hybridized by William Wolfskill (1798-1866) in the mid-1800s on his farm in Santa Ana, California, United States.

Popular cultivar. The large, sweet, seedless fruit have excellent flavour and plenty of juice. Ripens from mid to late-winter, and will hold well on the tree for several months. Scented white flowers throughout summer. Self-fertile. One of the best oranges to eat fresh. Citrus x sinensis is evergreen, a hybrid between Citrus reticulata and Citrus maxima, and native to China, India, and Myanmar. Learn more about Citrus x sinensis. Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' is believed to be a bud sport of Citrus x sinensis 'Selecta' that was found in the early 1880s. Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' was imported from Bahia, Brazil into the United States in 1870 where it was propagated by the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington, D.C. and then sent sent to California and Florida. Only the trees that went to Eliza Tibbets in Riverside, California thrived, and from there, Citrus x sinensis 'Washington Navel' was released into commerce.

Has attractive, yellow-green leaves that are mottled with dark-green and purple. New growth is quite purple. Birds adore the orange berries produced between mid-spring and mid-summer. Best in a sheltered site with cool soils and regular moisture. A great option for bush restoration. Small, white flowers in autumn. Coprosma autumnalis is evergreen and native to New Zealand and is widespread in both the North and South Island. Learn more about Coprosma autumnalis.

Fast-growing tree which clips into a nice hedge or screen. Very hardy tree which grows in most conditions. New growth is purple. Mature growth is attractive, glossy, dark, green-purple with purple undersides. Very adaptable to all conditions, including dry and exposed sites. Coprosma brockii is evergreen and native to New Zealand.

A low-growing native. Small, sage-green leaves are edged cream-white. Eye-catching contrast to lighten up areas. Excellent for containers. Great for groundcovers and low-hedges. Coprosma x kirkii is evergreen and a hybrid between Coprosma acerosa and Coprosma repens. Coprosma x kirkii is evergreen and native to New Zealand.

Thick, dark-green, glossy leaves. Excellent for coastal planting, being extremely tolerant of salt-laden harsh winds and drought. Use as a screening plant to shelter more tender plants and to filter out sand. Small, green-white flowers from mid-winter to mid-summer. Coprosma repens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma repens.

Has glossy, green leaves edged with yellow-orange during spring and summer. The leaves change to a dark-purple with red margins during autumn and winter. A trouble-free grower that requires little maintenance. An ideal patio plant. Coprosma repens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma repens. Coprosma repens 'Inferno' was bred by Peter John Fraser in Waikato, New Zealand (PVR 3106).

A prostrate form of Coprosma repens. Great for use as a groundcover in coastal gardens as it tolerates dry, windy conditions and is good for erosion control. Grows wider than it does high. Coprosma repens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma repens. Coprosma repens 'Poor Knights' is named after the Poor Knights Islands, New Zealand where it naturally grows. Coprosma repens 'Poor Knights' was supposedly first collected in 1769 by Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander on the HMS Endeavour.

A divaricating grower with tiny green leaves. Branch stems vary in colour from yellow-orange to red-orange. Very tough and tolerant of poor soil and dry conditions. Makes a superb, no-trim, narrow-growing hedge or screen. Coprosma virescens is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Coprosma virescens.

Suitable for group and specimen plantings, as well as containers. Hardy enough to grow in all situations and climates. Green leaves form large tufts. The stunning cream flowers are borne in large panicles in late-spring and perfume the air with their sweet fragrance. Produces fruit in mid-summer to early-autumn that birds adore. Cordyline australis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline australis.

A variegated form with green leaves broadly-margined with butter-yellow. Just as tough as Cordyline australis, but slower-growing and more slender. Particularly lovely as a container plant. Cordyline australis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline australis.

Has bronze-red, strap-like leaves. Coastal and frost tolerant once established. Best in full-sun in well-drained soil. Great for containers and adding colour to a garden. Cordyline australis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline australis. Cordyline australis 'Red Star' was produced by Twyford Laboratories in the United Kingdom.

Has broad leaves. Clump-forming, bushy, compact habit that is often multi-branched. Beautiful, drooping panicles of fragrant, white flowers in summer. Cordyline banksii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cordyline banksii.

Superb native with very wide, shorter, sword-like, green leaves and a compact habit. Ideal for containers and gardens of all sizes. Cordyline 'Broadsword' is evergreen and a hybrid between Cordyline obtecta and Cordyline australis. Cordyline 'Broadsword' was developed by Thirkettle Nurseries in Nelson, New Zealand (PVR 32779).

otherCommonNames: Cabbage Tree, Three Kings Cabbage Tree
description: Has broad, fresh-green leaves. Branches close to the ground and has a very compact head of leaves. Cordyline obtecta is evergreen and native to New Zealand and Norfolk Island. Learn more about Cordyline obtecta.

Has broad leaves of glossy, dark-purple. A sturdy grower which matures with multi-trunks. Produces panicles of small, white, fragrant flowers in early-spring. Excellent for large containers. Cordyline 'Renegade' is evergreen and a hybrid between Cordyline australis and Cordyline banksii. Cordyline 'Renegade' was produced by Dave Lloyd at Plantlife Propagators in Ashhurst, New Zealand (PVR 2655). Dave sowed seed of purple Cordyline australis in 1999 and from the resulting plants selected Cordyline 'Renegade'.

synonyms: Cornus sericea subsp. sericea 'Elegantissima', Cornus alba 'Sibirica Variegata', Cornus sericea subsp. sericea 'Sibirica Variegata', Cornus alba 'Argenteomarginata', Cornus sericea subsp. sericea 'Argenteomarginata'
description: Forms a thicket of erect, red stems. Bare stems in winter are a glowing-scarlet. Will tolerate very wet growing conditions. Green leaves with white margins and cream bunches of spring flowers, blue-white fruits follow. Cut back old stems to the ground every few years to promote new growth. Orange and red autumn leaves. Cornus alba is deciduous and native to Siberia, northern China, and Korea. Learn more about Cornus alba.

Forms a thicket of erect, red stems. Bare stems in winter are a glowing-scarlet. Will tolerate very wet growing conditions. Green leaves and cream bunches of spring flowers, blue-white fruits follow. Cut back old stems to the ground every few years to promote new growth. Orange and red autumn leaves. Cornus alba is deciduous and native to Siberia, northern China, and Korea. Learn more about Cornus alba. Cornus alba 'Sibirica' was introduced into commerce in the United Kingdom by the Loddiges family.

Small, green leaves edged with white give a silver appearance. Branches grow in tiers. Autumn leaves of red and purple. Clusters of cream-white flowers top the branches in early-summer. Cornus alternifolia is deciduous and native to eastern North America, from Newfoundland west to southern Manitoba and Minnesota, and south to northern Florida and Mississippi. Learn more about Cornus alternifolia. Cornus alternifolia 'Argentea' was put into commerce before 1900 by Temple and Beard in the United States.

otherCommonNames: Himalayan Flowering Dogwood, Himalayan Evergreen Dogwood, Himalayan Strawberry Tree, Bentham's Cornel, Strawberry Dogwood
description: The leaves are green with fuzzy undersides. White flower blooms during summer. Red fruit in autumn. Cornus capitata is evergreen and native to the low-elevation woodlands of the Himalayas in China, India, Pakistan, Nepal, and Bhutan. Learn more about Cornus capitata.

Picturesque, horizontal, sweeping branches in layered tiers. Glossy, dark-green leaves are glaucous beneath. They glow rich purple-red in autumn and this colour persists well into winter. Cream-white flowers sit atop the branches in late-spring to early-summer. Blue-purple to black fruit follow in late-summer to autumn which birds relish. Cornus controversa is deciduous and native to China, Korea, the Himalayas, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus controversa.

Beautifully tiered branches in layers have green leaves broadly-margined with gold. New spring growth is green with pink-orange edges. Cream-white flowers sit atop the branches in late-spring to early-summer. Blue-purple to black fruit follow in late-summer to autumn which birds relish. Red autumn leaves. Slow-growing tree which is spectacular as a specimen. Cornus controversa is deciduous and native to China, Korea, the Himalayas, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus controversa. Cornus controversa 'Golden Wedding' was produced in Taranaki, New Zealand by Vance Hooper (PVR 30959).

Beautifully tiered branches in layers have green leaves broadly-margined with cream. Cream-white flowers sit atop the branches in late-spring to early-summer. Blue-purple to black fruit follow in late-summer to autumn which birds relish. Yellow autumn leaves. Slow-growing tree which is spectacular as a specimen. Yellow autumn leaves. Cornus controversa is deciduous and native to China, Korea, the Himalayas, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus controversa. Cornus controversa 'Variegata' was cultivated in Japan in the mid-1800s and was introduced into Europe in 1889 by Veitch Nuseries in Exeter, England.

Upright-growing tree with tiered, semi-weeping branches. Large, flat, lime-green flowers age to white in late-spring. Small, red fruit in autumn until eaten by birds. Flowers well in warmer regions. Stunning autumn leaves of burnt-orange and scarlet. Excellent street tree. Ideal shade tree. Cornus 'Eddie's White Wonder' is deciduous and a hybrid between Cornus nuttallii and Cornus florida, discovered by nurseryman Henry Matheson Eddie (1881-1953) of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada in 1945, and has been commercially propagated since 1955.
images: cornus-eddies-white-wonder/cornus-eddies-white-wonder-early-autumn-leaves.jpg&cornus eddies white wonder early autumn leaves

description: Slender, erect trunk with dainty, tiered branches. Masses of four-petalled, white flowers face upwards in spring. Clusters of red fruit in autumn until eaten by birds. Vivid orange, red, and purple autumn leaves. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida.

A profusion of pretty, pink flowers in early-spring. Fresh-green spring leaves turn purple and red in autumn. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida.

Deep-red, large, flat, pink, four-petalled flowers in spring on bare branches. New spring growth is bronze-red. Deep-green, glossy leaves through summer. Yellow, scarlet, and wine-coloured leaves through autumn. Excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief' was discovered as a chance seedling by Isaac J. Hawkersmith growing at his nursery, Ike Hawkersmith Nursery, near Sweetwater, Tennessee, United States in the early 1950s. In 1958, Isaac was granted a patent (USPP1710P) for Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief'.

Large, green leaves have broad, cream margins and wavy edges. Bears a few large, white, flat flowers in early-spring. Exceptional foliage. Leaves in autumn turn salmon-pink to rose-purple. Excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Daybreak' was discovered by Hubert A. Nicholson as a chance seedling in Franklin County, Tennessee, United States (USPP6320P).

Has a low-branching, broadly-pyramidal form. Glossy, light-green leaves turn a fiery blend of orange and red in autumn. White flowers in mid-spring. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Princess' was developed by Isaac J. Hawkersmith at his nursery, Ike Hawkersmith Nursery, near Sweetwater, Tennessee, United States in 1950. Isaac originally named the tree Cornus florida 'Sno-White', before changing the name to Cornus florida 'Cherokee Princess'.

New, green leaves are variegated with cream-yellow and pink margins. Summer leaves are broadly-margined with yellow. Large, pink-red, flat flowers appear with spring leaves. Autumn leaves of red and purple. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cherokee Sunset' was discovered by Hubert A. Nicholson as a branch sport growing on a Cornus florida 'Cherokee Chief' in Franklin County, Tennessee, United States (USPP6305P).

Gives a massed display of large, flat, white flowers with overlapping bracts and prominent green eyes in spring from an early age. Flowers well in warmer climates. Strong-grower with an erect form. Yellow, scarlet, orange, and purple autumn leaves. Excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Cloud Nine' was developed by Chase Nursery in Chase, Alabama, United States and was patented in 1961 (USPP2112).

Yellow-variegated foliage, large yet delicate white blooms in spring, and an excellent wide-spreading form. Requires rich, well-drained soil and adequate precipitation, best with some shelter. Purple and red autumn leaves. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'First Lady' was discovered in 1957 by Fernando Campbell Boyd Jr. and was first observed flowering in 1967. Cornus florida 'First Lady' was put into commerce by Boyd Nursery Company in McMinnville, Tennessee, United States and received a patent in 1969 (USPP2916).

Golden spring leaves turn antique-gold in summer. Red autumn leaves with white spring flowers. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Old Gold' was developed by Peter Cave in New Zealand.

Slow-growing form with stiffly-weeping branches. In spring, the cream-white, flat flowers flow down the branches. Very beautiful and desirable. Autumn leaves of deep-purple and scarlet. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Pendula' was produced by Meehan's Nursery in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States before 1880 and was propagated from a Cornus florida tree discovered in Maryland, United States.

Has light-purple leaves in spring, maturing to dark-purple in summer before becoming a black-purple in autumn. The red spring flowers are long-lasting and showy. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Purple Glory' was found as a chance seedling by Clark Boyd of Boyd Nursery Company in McMinnville, Tennessee, United States in 1966. Cornus florida 'Purple Glory' was patented in 1979 (USPP4627).

Large, green leaves have golden margins. Brilliant autumn leaves in hues of rainbow-pink to carmine-red and lavender-blue to purple-red. White flowers appear with the new leaves in spring. Excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Rainbow' was found by Armond Marzilli as a sport from stump sprouts in Canton, Ohio, United States and was patented in 1967 (USPP2743).

Round-headed tree with a slender trunk and spreading branches. Large, rose-pink, four-petalled, flat flowers in spring. Vivid autumn leaves of orange, red, and wine-purple. Excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Spring Song' originated at Hoyt's Sons Nursery in New Canaan, Connecticut, United States and was registered with the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University in Boston, Massachusetts, United States in 1963.

Strong-grower with an ascending branch structure. Rich-pink, four-petalled flowers smother the branches in spring. Flowers well in warmer regions. Autumn leaves are rich-red and purple. These persist well into winter. Excellent street tree. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida.

A multi-stemmed tree with lower horizontal branching and an oval upper crown. Bears a profusion of cream-white, flat flowers in spring. The small red fruit are relished by birds. Stunning autumn leaves of maroon and red. Cornus florida is deciduous and native to eastern North America and northern Mexico. Learn more about Cornus florida. Cornus florida 'Weaver's White' appeared in the 1941 catalogue of Glen Saint Mary Nurseries Company in Glen Saint Mary, Florida, United States.

A vigorous, hardy, and highly-ornamental tree. Likes the sun and nice, rich soil. The large, cream-white flowers cover the plant in early-summer lasting for as long as 8 weeks. Beautiful autumn colours of orange and red. Cornus 'Greenvale' is semi-evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Cornus capitata and Cornus kousa that was discovered in Greenvale, Southland, New Zealand by L. Paterson (PVR 2854).

Vase-shaped when young, becoming more rounded with age. White flowers from late-spring to early-summer. Red fruit attracts birds. Green foliage turns purple-red in autumn. Hardy. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa.

Has glossy-green leaves. In youth, it is elegantly vase-shaped becoming more rounded with maturity. Deep-pink flowers in spring. Purple and red leaves in autumn. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Beni-fuji' was produced by Nobuo Yamashita, Hisao Ishikawa, Toshihiro Hagiwara at their nursery in Shinkyo, Gotenba-shi, Shizuoka-ken, Japan. In 1970, they planted a number of seeds they had collected from Cornus kousa trees growing on the southeastern slopes of Mount Fuji. In the subsequent years, they selected seedlings with an unusually high amount of red coloration in their leaves and the tips of their stems. Eventually, from this selection they selected Cornus kousa 'Beni-fuji' in June 1978 (USPP8676P).

Subtle blend of cream, soft-gold, and lime-green variegated leaves. Produces a mass of flat, four-petalled, white, star-shaped flowers in early-summer. Autumn leaves are a blend of red and burgundy. Bushy, erect grower. Excellent street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa.

Vigorous grower, flowering profusely at a very early age. Small flowers begin lime-green, gradually maturing and enlarging to four-petalled, snow-white flowers in early-summer. Erect, upright grower. Orange and red autumn leaves. Excellent street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'China Girl' has been cultivated since 1910, but was given its current cultivar name in 1978 to distinguish it from Cornus kousa var. chinensis.

Tall, upright grower. The large, white flowers in spring have extra bracts to give the flowers a semi-double effect. Red and orange autumn leaves. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa.

A distinctive cultivar with a rounded, growth habit. The cascading branches become smothered in large, white, flat, four-petalled flowers in early-summer. Red, strawberry-like fruit follow, which are relished by birds. Red autumn leaves. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' was selected by Baier Lustgarten from seedlings grown at Baier Lustgarten Farms and Nurseries in Long Island, New York, United States. Cornus kousa 'Elizabeth Lustgarten' was introduced into commerce by James Cross in Cutchogue, New York, United States and was registered with the Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University in Boston, Massachusetts, United States in 1978.

Horizontal branches grow in tiers. Beautiful leaves are pointy and deep-green with a bold, gold central stripe. Profusion of cream-white flowers in spring. Magnificent pink berries are borne through summer. Vivid brick-red autumn leaves. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Gold Star' was introduced in Japan in 1977 by the Sakata Nursery Company in Yokohama and then into commerce in the United States in 1983.

Vigorous grower. Becomes smothered with large, flat, four-petalled, white, star-shaped flowers in early-summer. Red strawberry-like fruit follows, which birds relish. Spectacular red and purple autumn leaves. Excellent street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Milky Way' originated at Wayside Gardens in Mentor, Ohio, United States in the 1960s.

Bears huge, flat flowers of cream-white with pink tips in spring and summer. Red fruit follow which birds relish. Forms a rounded tree well-suited to the smaller garden. Stunning red and maroon autumn leaves. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Moonbeam' was developed by Mary Wakefield in Milton, Massachusetts, United States and was patented in 1974 (USPP3482).

Vigorous grower. Becomes smothered with large, flat, four-petalled, ivory-white flowers in early-summer. Red strawberry-like fruit follow, which birds relish. Spectacular red and purple autumn leaves. Excellent street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa.

Vigorous grower. Becomes smothered with large, flat, four-petalled, pink-red, star-shaped flowers in early-summer. Red, strawberry-like fruit follow, which birds relish. Spectacular red and purple autumn leaves. Excellent street tree. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Satomi' was developed by Akiri Shibamichi, a Japanese nurseryman, and named after his granddaughter. The exact time of development is unknown, but Cornus kousa 'Satomi' has been in cultivation in the United States since 1986.

Becomes smothered with large, flat, four-petalled, cream-white, star-shaped flowers in early-summer. Red strawberry-like fruit follow, which birds relish. Red autumn leaves hold well into winter in cooler climates. Excellent for the smaller garden. Cornus kousa is deciduous and native to East Asia including Korea, China, and Japan. Learn more about Cornus kousa. Cornus kousa 'Southern Cross' was developed in New Zealand.

Tall, willow-like grower with tiered, semi-weeping branches. Large, flat, six-petalled, green flowers age white before flushing soft-pink. Flowers late-spring and then again in late-summer or early-autumn. Large, green leaves turn yellow and red in autumn. Cornus nuttallii is deciduous and native to western North America. Learn more about Cornus nuttallii.

Forms a thicket of erect, golden stems which glow in winter when bare. Will tolerate very wet growing conditions. A magnificent sight when mass-planted. Cut back to the ground every few years to promote new growth. Red and orange autumn leaves. Small clusters of tiny, cream-white flowers in late-spring. Cornus sericea is deciduous and native to much of North America. Learn more about Cornus sericea. Cornus sericea 'Flaviramea' was put into commerce by Späth Nursery in Berlin, Germany in 1899.

A slender, erect, multi-branched grower with dense, interlacing branches. Excellent for screening and hedging. Becomes smothered in spring with bright, canary-yellow flowers. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Very hardy for windy and dry positions. Corokia x cheesemanii is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x cheesemanii is evergreen and native to New Zealand.

A slender, erect, multi-branched grower with dense, interlacing branches. Glossy, slender, green and red-brown leaves that deepen their bronze colour in winter. Becomes smothered in star-shaped, bright-yellow flowers in spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Bronze King' was developed in New Zealand.

A very compact and tidy grower with green leaves on silver stems. Star-shaped, yellow flowers in spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Excellent as a low hedge or screen. Drought and coastal hardy. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Emerald and Jade' was developed in New Zealand.

description: A dense, erect-growing, multi-branched grower. Has large, glossy, green and chocolate-brown leaves that deepen in colour in winter. Becomes smothered in star-shaped, bright-yellow flowers during spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Excellent for formal hedging in dry and windy positions. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Frosted Chocolate' was developed in New Zealand.

A compact, dwarf-grower with slender, dark-green leaves that have a silver sheen. Clips into any shape, so ideal for containers and edging gardens. Drought and coastal hardy. Small, yellow flowers in spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Ghost' was developed before 2002 by M. F. Geenty in Hamilton, New Zealand (PVR 2531).

Hardy. Excellent for screening with longer green leaves than Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Green'. Masses of small, yellow, daisy flowers in spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Giant' was developed by M. F. Geenty in Hamilton, New Zealand.

A dense, erect-growing, multi-branched grower. Has large, glossy, green leaves. Becomes smothered in star-shaped, bright-yellow flowers during spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Excellent for formal hedging in dry, windy positions. Can be shaped into any form. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Geenty's Green' was developed by M. F. Geenty in Hamilton, New Zealand.

description: Has silver-green foliage. Small, yellow flowers in spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Great for hedging. Tolerates dry and windy conditions. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata.

A dense, bushy grower with brown-green to brown-black leaves through spring, summer, and autumn. During winter, the leaves turn almost black. Tolerates dry and windy sites. Small, yellow flowers in spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Great for low hedging, containers, and topiary. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata. Corokia x virgata 'Phantom' was developed by City Park Services in Auckland, New Zealand (PVR 30655).

A dense, bushy grower with dark-green leaves through spring, summer, and autumn. Tolerates dry and windy sites. Small, yellow flowers in spring. Produces red, orange, or yellow berries in autumn which birds adore. Great for low hedging, containers, and topiary. Corokia x virgata is a hybrid between Corokia buddleioides and Corokia cotoneaster. Corokia x virgata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corokia x virgata.

A vigorous grower and good producer of large nuts. Harvest red-orange to brown nuts in late-summer to early-autumn. Pollinators include Corylus avellana 'Butler', Corylus avellana 'Merveille de Bollwiller', and Corylus avellana 'Tonda di Giffoni'. Hazelnut trees prefer mild summers and cool winters and need protection from wind and high summer temperatures. Ideal temperatures are an anual average of 12°C to 16°C, maximum of 35°C to 36°C, and a minimum of -8°C to -10°C. Ideal annual rainfall is 800mm to 1000mm, spread evenly throughout the growing season. Irrigation will be needed for areas that experience prolonged dry periods from late-spring to mid-summer, especially if the soil is free-draining (sandy or stony). Corylus avellana is evergreen and native to Europe and western Asia. Learn more about Corylus avellana. Corylus avellana 'Barcelona' is an old cultivar widely distributed in Western Europe and probably originated in Spain. Corylus avellana 'Barcelona' has been the main cultivar grown in Oregon, United States since the mid-1800s.

Produces large, quality nuts on a vigorous growing tree. Harvest red-orange to brown nuts in late-summer to early-autumn. A useful pollinator for other hazelnut cultivars like Corylus avellana 'Barcelona' and Corylus avellana 'Whiteheart'. Hazelnut trees prefer mild summers and cool winters and need protection from wind and high summer temperatures. Ideal temperatures are an anual average of 12°C to 16°C, maximum of 35°C to 36°C, and a minimum of -8°C to -10°C. Ideal annual rainfall is 800mm to 1000mm, spread evenly throughout the growing season. Irrigation will be needed for areas that experience prolonged dry periods from late-spring to mid-summer, especially if the soil is free-draining (sandy or stony). Corylus avellana is evergreen and native to Europe and western Asia. Learn more about Corylus avellana. Corylus avellana 'Merveille de Bollwiller' originated in 1788 as a seedling selection by C. G. Bultner in Halle, Germany.

description: Produces good crops of small, round nuts that are used mainly for processing. Harvest red-orange to brown nuts in late-summer to early-autumn. Pollinators include Corylus avellana 'Alexandra', Corylus avellana 'Auckland No. 2', and Corylus avellana 'Merveille de Bollwiller'. Hazelnut trees prefer mild summers and cool winters and need protection from wind and high summer temperatures. Ideal temperatures are an anual average of 12°C to 16°C, maximum of 35°C to 36°C, and a minimum of -8°C to -10°C. Ideal annual rainfall is 800mm to 1000mm, spread evenly throughout the growing season. Irrigation will be needed for areas that experience prolonged dry periods from late-spring to mid-summer, especially if the soil is free-draining (sandy or stony). Corylus avellana is evergreen and native to Europe and western Asia. Learn more about Corylus avellana. Corylus avellana 'Whiteheart' was selected in the 1980s by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Erect, conical-grower with a very symmetrical branching habit. Produces edible brown nuts in autumn, although they are encased in a thick, hard, green shell that makes them difficult to extract. Fruiting is irregular, occurring every two to three years. Tolerates hot, dry climates. Excellent street tree. Has corky bark. Yellow-green catkins from early-spring to early-summer are a source of pollen for bees. Yellow autumn leaves. Has a deep rooting system, and does not transplant well. Corylus colurna is deciduous and native to southeast Europe and southwest Asia, from the Balkans through northern Turkey to northern Iran. Learn more about Corylus colurna.

Sturdy, single-trunked tree with a round-headed, compact crown. Large, thick, green leaves. Flowers in mid-summer with variations of glowing red, orange, and pink. Flowers attract nectar-seeking birds. Tolerant of drought and coastal winds. Corymbia ficifolia is evergreen and native to Western Australia. Learn more about Corymbia ficifolia.

Handsome, upright-growing tree with large, glossy, leathery, deep-green leaves. Grows naturally alongside waterways. Tolerates moderate coastal winds, frosts once established, and dry conditions. Large, orange fruit in late summer are relished by wood pigeons. Corynocarpus laevigatus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Corynocarpus laevigatus.

Lime and golden foliage throughout spring and summer, which lightens up dark areas and adds contrast. Beautiful autumn foliage of orange and red. May not flower as well as other Cotinus cultivars. If flowering does occur, it will be pink flower plumes on old wood in mid-summer. Best grown in part-shade. Keep moist. Cotinus coggygria is deciduous and native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia and the Himalayas to northern China. Learn more about Cotinus coggygria. Cotinus coggygria 'Golden Spirit' was discovered in 1989 in Boskoop, Netherlands by Sanders-van Harn and Adriana Christina Bastiana (USPP13082).

New leaves are red, maturing to green tinged with blue. Fluffy heads of pink-red flowers cover the bush in early-summer. Stunning autumn leaves of orange, red, and purple. Can trim into any shape or form. Cotinus coggygria is deciduous and native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia and the Himalayas to northern China. Learn more about Cotinus coggygria. Cotinus coggygria 'Red Spirit' was developed by Miyoshi & Co. Ltd. in Japan.

Large, bushy grower with attractive, rounded leaves. New spring leaves are a rich maroon-red, maturing to a deep wine-purple over summer, then turning more red in autumn. Large, pink, feathery flower plumes appear in spring giving the tree a smoke-like appearance. Cotinus coggygria is deciduous and native to a large area from southern Europe, east across central Asia and the Himalayas to northern China. Learn more about Cotinus coggygria. Cotinus coggygria 'Royal Purple' was selected by Lombarts Nursery in Boskoop, Netherlands and was introduced into the United States in 1953.

Purple leaves in spring and summer that turn a vibrant orange and red in autumn. Large, conical, purple-pink flower clusters are borne in summer. A strong, upright-grower with a rounded head. Excellent street tree. Cotinus 'Grace' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Cotinus coggygria 'Velvet Cloak' and a male Cotinus obovatus. Cotinus 'Grace' was developed in 1978 by Peter Dummer at Hillier Nurseries in Ampfield, United Kingdom. Peter named Cotinus 'Grace' after his wife.

Vigorous grower with purple-pink new leaves that fade to blue-green. Amazing autumn colours of red, orange, and purple leaves. Plume-like, pink flower-heads are borne over summer. Does well in poor soil and is grown primarily for its brilliant autumn colour. Drought-tolerant when established and will tolerate urban pollution. Cotinus obovatus is deciduous and native to scattered locations in the states of Oklahoma, Texas, Arkansas, Missouri, Alabama, and Tennessee in the United States. Learn more about Cotinus obovatus.

otherCommonNames: Midland Hawthorn, English Hawthorn, Woodland Hawthorn
description: Upright tree with a compact, rounded head. Impressive heads of double crimson-red flowers smother the tree in late-spring. Produces red fruits in autumn that birds love. Excellent street tree. Doesn't develop any appreciable autumn colour. Branches have thorns. A very tough tree that will grow in almost all conditions. Crataegus x media is a hybrid between Crataegus monogyna and Crataegus laevigata. Crataegus x media is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Crataegus x media. Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' originated in 1858 as a sport growing on a Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' in the garden of Christopher Boyd near Waltham Cross, England. Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' was propagated by William Paul and unveiled at the International Horticultural Exhibition of 1866.
tolerates: windy, coastal, drought, heavy-rainfall, light-frosts, heavy-frosts

description: Quickly grows into a tall, stately tree. Foliage grows from the ground to become an excellent shelter tree. Lovely, enduring specimen tree with a pyramidal form. Tolerant of strong winds. Cryptomeria japonica is evergreen and native to Japan. Learn more about Cryptomeria japonica.

Selected form of Cryptomeria japonica with superior form, wind hardiness, and growth rate. Makes a good screen or hedge, and can be pruned. Will tolerate all but the most severe coastal conditions. Cryptomeria japonica is evergreen and native to Japan. Learn more about Cryptomeria japonica. Cryptomeria japonica 'Egmont' was developed by Cedar Lodge Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

New foliage emerges bronze-red and matures to a beautiful glossy, dark-green. Large, fragrant, white panicles of flowers resembling candles are borne through summer. Ideal for the smaller garden. Does not like windy conditions or hot and dry weather. Prefers a more temperate climate that mimics the sheltered forest environment where it occurs naturally. Does not have an invasive root system and can be grown in large pots. Cunonia capensis is evergreen and native to southern Africa. Learn more about Cunonia capensis.

synonyms: Hesperocyparis arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice', Callitropsis arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice'
description: Compact, pyramidal-growing conifer with smooth, frosted, blue leaves. Very amenable to pruning into any shape or form. Quick-growing and hardy to strong winds and drought. Makes an excellent dense shelter. Almost immune to cypress canker. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra is evergreen and native to a wide area around Sedona, Arizona, United States. Learn more about Cupressus arizonica. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice' was discovered as a chance seedling in 1960 by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and introduced by them into commerce in 1984.
